physDesc.p: This letter consists of three typed pages on carbon paper. The upper lefthand corner of the first page consists of an address heading. The righthand consists of a dateline. Above the dateline after the first page is a heading (Mr. Aldington - [Page #]). There are some tears on the right edges of the third page, and folds on the upper right corners of the first and second pages.

div.p: I have not had any luck with your things, except the one I sold to Miss Cutting and which I am dreadfully afraid you had already sold to Miss Monroe. You sent it to me before this second batch in which you had a list of the people to whom you had sold things. I have warned Miss Cutting, as the “North American” will publish nothing which has appeared before. In sending me things to place, it is usually quite useless to send me anything which has appeared anywhere, even in England, but nothing which has appeared in America, and none of the better established magazines will take anything which has been printed anywhere.

Stewart Mitchell wrote and asked me to send him all your poems which I had, but I am sorry to say that he has returned them all to me, and also your “Influence of Mr. James Joyce.” I may be able to place the poems, I am not sure. The best ones you have already sold. There is not the slightest use of my thinking I can place this article on Joyce anywhere. Nobody reads Joyce here. The article could only hurt you, for most of the people who know anything about him thoroughly detest him, I am therefore returning this manuscript to you. In many ways America is less open minded than England. He may have some influence in England - you seem to think so in your paper - but I hardly think he could have any here. What he is doing is harm, for where other writers speak plainly and honestly with a high intent, as Lawrence does, Joyce is merely obscene, and the Watch and Ward Society, etc. are perfectly incapable of telling the difference between obscenity and truth. The obvious disgustingness of Joyce's work would simply bring the strong and true work of better men than he into strong disrepute. Too bad, because yours is a good paper, but there is no place for the subject over
here now. The more I know of our two countries the more I realize that we are following entirely different literary orbits. There is simply no audience for Joyce over here, except among certain of the intelligentsia. I am awfully sorry, but there is no use in my trying to do anything with this paper, I know. If you will send me another paper asggood (sic) as this, but about some writer whom the public knows, I make no doubt I can place it most satisfactorily anywhere.

Meanwhile my own news is none too good. I am to be cut up again during the week of October 18th. It is a pesky nuisance, but I have seen the biggest man in the country on hernias, in New York, and he thinks that the other operations have not been properly done and that there are nine cases out of ten in favour of recovery. I have also got the chief surgeon in Boston on the job, and the two of them are going to perform the next operation, and I have some hopes of success. Unless it is successful, I see my life growing narrower and narrower as I become more unable to do things, so we will hope for the best, for, except for this bothersome thing, I have never been better in my life and am eager for work and in full train, which makes things particularly annoying.

I will send you some poems before long, but the truth of the matter is that I am so constantly sold up here that I do not get round to keeping things to send to England, which seems remote as I have no real public there yet. I have already lost three months this year, and this operation means another three months. Six months out of a year greatly diminishes my output.

At the moment, I am working on another volume of poems to appear in the Spring, as I have changed my publisher, Macmillan not having lived up to his contracts, and Houghton Mifflin having made me a very good offer to return to them, which I have accepted; and of course they want a new book to
make an advertising campaign on in the Spring. Just now I am working very hard to live up to my already incurred obligations before the 18th of October.

Write me often, as I shall certainly need letters to keep me up during the long weeks when I must lie flat on my back. Monro has asked me to send him some things for the “Chapbook,” but again I have not got round to it.
No more for the present, as I am in a great hurry trying to finish things up.
